posts.post_content:
I use a couple of these as bait for [Gilded Drake](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gilded Drake). Works surprisingly well. Oh your going to grab Emrakul? Well here, why don't I take that and you just have this 3/3 Flying instead?  
  
Very fun, very well made card. Has a lot of potential, but you can't just drop it blindly without asking for trouble.
posts.html:
I use a couple of these as bait for Gilded Drake. Works surprisingly well. Oh your going to grab Emrakul? Well here, why don't I take that and you just have this 3/3 Flying instead?

Very fun, very well made card. Has a lot of potential, but you can't just drop it blindly without asking for trouble.

Posted By: eak1801 (12/18/2010 3:16:47 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
MarlinFlake  
"Emrakul can't be targeted by colored spells"  
1) A **spell** is any **card** that is on the **stack**  
2) Colored **abilities** like those of [fatestitcher](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=fatestitcher), [Cunning Sparkmage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cunning Sparkmage) and [Gilded Drake](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gilded Drake) are **not cards** and therefore **not spells**, **however** if those cards were on the stack and used those abilities on the stack then they can not target Emrakul because there sources are from colored spells   
3) "When 'Name' enters the battlefield" is a triggered ability from something on the battlefield and not the stack  
4) I can read just fine and eak1801 I'm taking your combo :D
posts.html:
MarlinFlake
"Emrakul can't be targeted by colored spells"
1) A spell is any card that is on the stack
2) Colored abilities like those of fatestitcher, Cunning Sparkmage and Gilded Drake are not cards and therefore not spells, however if those cards were on the stack and used those abilities on the stack then they can not target Emrakul because there sources are from colored spells
3) "When 'Name' enters the battlefield" is a triggered ability from something on the battlefield and not the stack
4) I can read just fine and eak1801 I'm taking your combo :D

posts.post_content:
I think that it's worth pointing out the control potential of a card like this. Your opponent gets the chance to put his best creature on the battlefield for free, and if you're smart, you'll have a way to deal with it.   
  
True, you could destroy it with [t Breaking Point](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=t Breaking Point) as suggested, but that requires your opponent to already be in such a tight spot that killing every creature is preferable to taking six damage. Leave some mana open for a [Traitorous Instinct](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Traitorous Instinct), [Act of Treason](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Act of Treason) or other such red one-turn control card (or a blue one, maybe, but Giants and blue seem to be at odds with each other), grab your opponent's [Kozilek, Butcher of Truth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kozilek, Butcher of Truth) or [Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre) and laugh at his shocked expression. Of course, there's a long list of ways this could go wrong (the list being comprised of every significant creature with protection from red, shroud, or a notable come-into-play abilit... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
I think that it's worth pointing out the control potential of a card like this. Your opponent gets the chance to put his best creature on the battlefield for free, and if you're smart, you'll have a way to deal with it.

True, you could destroy it with t Breaking Point as suggested, but that requires your opponent to already be in such a tight spot that killing every creature is preferable to taking six damage. Leave some mana open for a Traitorous Instinct, Act of Treason or other such red one-turn control card (or a blue one, maybe, but Giants and blue seem to be at odds with each other), grab your opponent's Kozilek, Butcher of Truth or Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre and laugh at his shocked expression. Of course, there's a long list of ways this could go wrong (the list being comprised of every significant creature with protection from red, shroud, or a notable come-into-play abilit... (see all)

posts.post_content:
The savest and simplest way to play this should be with [Grafdigger's Cage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Grafdigger's Cage) or [Stranglehold](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stranglehold) on the field.  
[Leonin Arbiter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leonin Arbiter) works too if you play white, but only if your opponents can't afford to pay ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol).  
[Control-changing](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=202411) or [bounce](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=220301) effects should be awesome as well - unless your opponent brings a creature with shroud or hexproof).  
Or simply stick to good old [Stifle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stifle).
posts.html:
The savest and simplest way to play this should be with Grafdigger's Cage or Stranglehold on the field.
Leonin Arbiter works too if you play white, but only if your opponents can't afford to pay .
Control-changing or bounce effects should be awesome as well - unless your opponent brings a creature with shroud or hexproof).
Or simply stick to good old Stifle.
